Create_a_CLI_tool_that_converts_a_Markdo.task_raw_name: Create a CLI tool that converts a Markdown file to HTML. The tool should be in a 'src' directory. It must use the 'markdown2' library. It should take a source file path as a command-line argument and print the resulting HTML to the console. Create a 'tests' directory with a pytest file to test the conversion logic.

_200_Build_a_Python_command_line_tool_th.task_raw_name:
[200~Build a Python command-line tool that analyzes the sentiment of text files using a third-party natural language processing library.

2️⃣ Functionality:

The tool takes a source file path as a command-line argument.

The file will contain plain text (assume .txt file).

Your tool reads the file contents.

It uses the TextBlob library (or any other NLP library you select and install via pip) to perform sentiment analysis.

It prints the sentiment polarity and subjectivity scores to the console.

The console output should include:

File name being analyzed.

Sentiment polarity (range -1 to 1).

Sentiment subjectivity (range 0 to 1).

3️⃣ Directory Structure:

css
Copy
Edit
project_root/
├── src/
│   └── sentiment_analyzer.py
└── tests/
    └── test_sentiment_analyzer.py
4️⃣ Testing:

Write unit tests in the tests/ directory using pytest.

Include at least 3 test cases covering:

Positive sentiment.

Negative sentiment.

Neutral sentiment.

The tests should call the core sentiment analysis function directly (not via CLI).

5️⃣ Other Requirements:

Follow Python best practices.

Include error handling for:

File not found.

Empty files.

Non-text file formats.

Ensure proper docstrings and type hints.

6️⃣ Installation Instructions:

Use requirements.txt to specify dependencies.

7️⃣ Creativity:

You may improve or extend the design as you see fit.

You may include logging or enhanced output formatting if appropriate.

✅ When finished, your code must be executable by simply running:~
